David Plass wrote:

> Well, that wouldn't compile then.
> 
> In my example, I wanted to test the behavior that method.throwsNPE only
> throws NPE under certain circumstances (e.g., null argument.)
> In other words, I wanted to test the throwsNPE's "contract" (flames to
> /dev/null)  that it throws NPE when it says it will.
> 
> If method.throwsNPE could also throw IOException, but my test case wanted to
> verify that it should NOT throw IOException in this circumstance, then I'd
> change the test method to the following:
> 
>      public void testExceptions() {    // note no throws
>          try {
>              method.throwsNPE();
>              fail("Should have thrown NPE");
>          } catch (NullPointerException expected) {
>              assertTrue("Should catch NPE", true);
>          } catch (IOException notExpected) {
>              fail("Unexpected IOException");
>          }
>      }
> 
> Then your next question might be, "what if it can throw a third exception"?
> After a while (maybe after just one more exception) I'd probably just cave
> and write "throws Exception".

Right.

The community has had long, long discussions about this 
exception-testing pattern, and the consensus seems to be this: catching 
an unexpected exception and failing buys no value over letting JUnit 
catch the exception; therefore, simply throw those exceptions up to 
JUnit. The corollary seems to be, just have every test throw Exception.

Of course, if you find value in the above, then I'm not going to tell 
you to stop. I'm just pointing out what we've been saying for a few 
years in case that information should be useful.

Thanks.
